instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936A: What is 820-2936A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.C1803: What is C1803? Capacitor to ground on RTC_RESET_L on machines from 2009-2012, RTC_RESET_L needs to be high for system to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board had severe liquid damage but since then have replaced all components that had liquid damage.

I now have green light and have all power rails leading up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is missing. Already replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

PPBUS 12.60V

12.59v on pin 16 <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>

<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C1803</CAPACITOR> are 2.882 V

Also <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0v. Does this automatically mean dead pch?


what to check or try next?

Only RTC region and CMOS registries of PCH are powered from <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> presence.

threads.message: Could be thunderbolt circuit, could be corrosion under SMC, bad BIOS traces, firewire chip... that board is terrible looking.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"all 4 RTC signals"
Almost always, people posting only two.
As the other two don't have "RTC" in the name, nobody pay atention.
But schematic clearly show them connected to PCH's RTC block...

Y5010 oscillates?
Do you have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present?
Check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is also low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 2.849v

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 2.201v

Y5010 is not oscillating and is at a steady 1.578V

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0v

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.017v

Put board in ultrasonic again earlier since liquid damage was so bad. Before board was drawing 0.20amps and now the board is using 0.142 amps and <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is very hot. I already replaced it but still very hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"Y5010 is not oscillating and is at a steady 1.578V"
I mean oscillates on o-scope...
1.5V is close to normal value, but DC voltage cannot assure you for proper oscillation.

"<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0v"
This doesn't depend by PCH, is controlled by SMC.

If <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> heats after UC, probably some traces got broken, or some components fall out.
UC without sweep function is a danger for logic board, if you let it various minutes in the same position; read about "hot spot" for cavitation.
Check for any short (L7220/60 maybe) and missing caps (<CAPACITOR>C7220</CAPACITOR>/60?) around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

Never power up a board after replacing of a hot component.
Think first, why was getting hot???
There could be other reason...

Post its voltages.

threads.message:
"l7260 0.036"
That's no good.
Remove power and wait 20s before measure diode mode on board...
Measure both directions, red and black at ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
0.007 in diode mode is aprox 10-15 ohms in 200ohm scale.
Something is strange with your measures...

Put red probe on ground and touch the coil with black probe; note the value.
Invert the probes and note the other (reverse) value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Remove F7040 and see if get correct voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR>.
If OK, then the problem is not on the power supply; which seems to be correct, but is better to discard 100%.

Looks like a short around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, or the chip itself.
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> and high-side of <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> for short.
Also check at VREG3/5 and VREF outputs...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Start from zero...
Disconnect everything from the board; leave only magsafe connected, nor even RAM is needed.
If <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> gets VIN and EN0, it should generate VREF, VREG3 and VREG5.

If ENTRIP2 has 0.75V, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> should also appear.
Both EN0 and ENTRIP2 are controlled by <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>; so should appear at the same moment.

If ENTRIP2 has 0.9V, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> should also appear.
This is controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

Low voltage at VREG5 can only be caused by <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> itself, or external component sinking to much current.
Start removing chips connected there.
<RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR> will isolate <CHIP>U5805</CHIP> area.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7840</TRANSISTOR> will separate <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>; you can also check for short directly there.
<CAPACITOR>C7273</CAPACITOR>, near <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, need to be removed for checking. Also U/<CAPACITOR>C7801</CAPACITOR> need remove to check.
